abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings suggest a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, although only modest
            institutional development impacts, but achieved through
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Lessons
            of experience suggest that "Adaptable Program
            Loans" may not be sufficiently adaptable when a project
            succeeds in convincing policymakers that the project merits
            replication and expansion. When the pace of change is such
            that the originally conceived program grows much faster than
            envisioned, the APL framework may actually inhibit
            adaptation, versus the use of a series of follow-up
            projects. Projects that finance small, demand-driven
            community subprojects through decentralized implementation
            structures, must greatly simplify financial management
            processes, especially those related to the validation of
            disbursements and expenditures. Attention should be given to
            establishing output/outcome-related approaches, and having
            as well a capacity building approach for best practices in
            management, and the administration of inputs incorporated
            into project and community subproject design. Mainstreaming
            and scaling-up of projects is extremely desirable from many
            perspectives. However, from a project management perspective
            there are risks that must be dealt with in an intentional
            fashion. Scaling-up too fast, rapidly increases the
            administrative complexity, and can dilute the administrative
            and technical capacities directed toward project
            implementation as well as limit the potential impact, and
            ability to innovate and learn. Finally, the program
            demonstrated that technical assistance is a very important
            factor in triggering and fostering rural development in
            marginal areas, and that upstream, preparatory work in
            participatory social diagnosis, and planning are essential
            tools for reaching the poor, and tailoring actions to what
            is appropriate to their situation.
